discussion.content: This has to be D
This is basically "DHCP reservation". Which mean you can provide pre-set IP address based on a client's physical MAC address.

D. Reservation

A reservation is an IP address that is assigned to a network device based on its MAC address. This is often used in DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) to ensure that a specific device always receives the same IP address, even if the network is using dynamic IP addressing. By reserving an IP address for a specific MAC address, administrators can ensure that a particular device is always reachable at the same IP address.

A dynamic IP address is assigned to a network device by a DHCP server, and can change each time the device connects to the network.

A static IP address is manually assigned to a network device, and does not change unless it is manually reconfigured.

A link-local address is a type of IP address used in local networks that do not have a DHCP server.

comments.content: However the DHCP also assigns by the MAC address by using a broadcast via ethernet so the answer technically is all of them

discussion.content: So I did some research to find out why they said Link Local... Apparently in IPv6 the Link Local address is derived from interface media access control (MAC) address in a rule-based method.

n computer networking, a link-local address is a network address that is valid only for communications within the network segment or the broadcast domain that the host is connected to. Link-local addresses are most often assigned automatically with a process known as stateless address autoconfiguration or link-local address autoconfiguration, also known as automatic private IP addressing or auto-IP. A link-local address is an IPv6 unicast address that can be automatically configured on any interface using the link-local prefix FE80::/10 (1111 1110 10) and the interface identifier in the modified EUI-64 format. Link-local addresses are not necessarily bound to the MAC address (configured in a EUI-64 format). Link-local addresses can also be manually configured in the FE80::/10 format using the ipv6 address link-local command. Ans is D.
Indeed reservations are made based on entering MAC address. Ans is D.
Why do you think that?

Yes, the new card requires more power than the PSU is able to supply which is preventing the PC from booting up properly. That is why the monitor is displaying a "No Signal" message, the graphics card isn't functioning.

tone generator and probe
The answer for this should be C and F. You can't utilize a cable tester until you can find the other end in the network closet.

Selected Answer: CF
Which of the following are the BEST tools for the technician to use to identify the correct network run to troubleshoot?
How is this not toner and probe
integrity of the wire = multimeter, identify which cable came from (wiremap) = cable tester Tone = end of the cable

From Mike Myers Comptia a+ books: 
When the time comes to trace cables, network techs turn to a device called a toner for help. Toner is the generic term for two separate devices that are used together: a tone generator and a tone probe. The tone generator connects to the cable using alligator clips, tiny hooks, or a network jack, and it sends an
electrical signal along the wire at a certain frequency. The tone probe emits a sound when it is placed near a cable connected to the tone generator. These two devices are often referred to by the brand-name Fox and Hound, a popular model of toner made by the Triplett Corporation.

The technician has two plans 1, verifying the integrity and 2, identifying the cables. Inorder to check the integrity of the cables s/he must work on identifying the cables first, and the question also is about identifying. Therefore, C and F is the right answer.
B & C of course
To identify that's C and F Guys.

Which of the following are the BEST tools for the technician to use to identify the correct network run to troubleshoot? (Choose two.)
He just needs to first of all identify. That is Tone Generator and Probe
Then he will start troubleshooting
C and F
